text.p: These are the leading stories in the Pakistani press on Saturday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Pakistan has successfully concluded talks with the Aid-to-Pakistan Consortium and the International Monetary Fund which are expected to finalise $1.5 billion new agreements on extended structural adjustment facility in September.
- Vice-Admiral Fasih Bokhari has been appointed as Chief of the Naval Staff with immediate effect with the rank of admiral.
- Commercial banks are seeking tough foreclosure laws to salvage bad assets without any loss of time.

- The government has decided to postpone the privatisation of Pakistan Telecommunications Company Ltd in the near future because of its huge financial liabilities, Communications Minister Azam Hoti said.
- Prime ministers of India and Pakistan exchanged messages of goodwill on telephone on Friday.
- Pakistan has welcomed the election of Tony Blair as the Prime Minister of Britain.

- Despite immense pressure from different quarters, the government is considering a cut in the buyback average tariff of 6.5 cents per unit, offered to private power projects, by levelling it at 5.9 cents.
- Private investors in power sector have warned that if the government continued its "unjustified" policy to renegotiate the tariff structure they may stop further investment in the country.
- Rice exporters have proposed to the government to introduce minimum export price.

- Former prime minister Benazir Bhutto has opposed a proposed bill likelt to be moved by the government before the parliament under which the courts would not be empowered to give bails to accused in certain cases.
